Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Large: Collaborative Research: Foundations of Hierarchical Full-Duplex Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop foundational principles for hierarchical wireless network design by leveraging full-duplex transmissions in both access and wireless backhaul. Full-duplex is most promising at shorter ranges, and hence is fortuitously aligned with the predicted dominant access range in future networks. Furthermore, larger full-duplex ranges are feasible in infrastructure-to-infrastructure links, and hence are well suited for backhaul links. While full-duplex is well-aligned with the key elements of hierarchical networks, our current design principles are largely developed for half-duplex transmissions which is the basis for all current networks. With that in mind, this project will address both theory and protocols for hierarchical full-duplex networks by looking at: (1) data-driven signal models for self-interference caused by the node's own transmission to its own receiver, (2) theoretical foundations for scheduling and routing that leverage both self-interference and multi-hop interference cancellation; and (3) protocols and prototypes for network scale full-duplex resource management.

Full-duplex breaks one of the basic design constraints in current wireless networks, all of which are either half-duplex in time or frequency; it will therefore rewrite wireless networking fundamentals. Further, with emphasis on realizable networks using extensive Rice University's programmable testbeds, the project will impact the next-generation of wireless networks via its corporate partners. Finally, the project team will establish a unique inter-university education and research program, which will include joint advising and collaborative advising and leverage the team's complementary expertise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, our overarching goal was to develop foundational principles for hierarchical wireless network design by leveraging full-duplex transmissions in both access and wireless backhaul. Full-duplex is most promising at shorter ranges, and hence is fortuitously aligned with the predicted dominant access range in future networks. Furthermore, larger full-duplex ranges are feasible in infrastructure-to-infrastructure links, and hence are well suited for backhaul links. While full-duplex is well-aligned with the key elements of hierarchical networks, our current design principles are largely developed for half-duplex transmissions which is the basis for all current networks. The project goals were to develop data-driven signal models for full-duplex to facilitate information-theoretic analyses and foundations for network-scale resource allocation.

In collaboration with Rice and OSU several new ideas were developed at UCLA to to advance the theory of full-duplex and address some of the most challenging conceptual bottlenecks. There were many new scientific results that were discovered and published during the course of this project, with details in the publicationsas well as summarized in annual reports of the project. We would like to highlight the following: (i) We designed and developed a new cellular architecture that combines multiuser MIMO (MU-MIMO) downlink with opportunistic (full-duplex) use of unlicensed ISM bands to establish device-to-device (D2D) cooperation. We developed new scheduling algorithms and theoretically demonstrated its performance through a utility maximization framework. We also evaluated the performance in large-scale simulations, demonstrating gains of upto 6x improvement in data rate for cell-edge users (over the state-of-the-art multi-user MIMO). (ii) Approximate characterization of fading interference channel capacity, an open problem in literature. For full-duplex nodes using feedback, we developed simpler point-to-point codes to achieve this approximate optimality. (iii) We developed a new method to harnessing intermittent feedback in full-duplex interference channels. We showed using a deterministic approximation approach, how unreliable feedback can be harnessed to provide multiplicative capacity gain in Gaussian interference channel. We also approximately characterized the capacity of such interference networks. (iv) We developed a new co-operative relaying scheme based on quantize-map-forward relaying, that also incorporated hybrid decoding, and implemented it on WARP radios, demonstrating through over-the- air experiments up to 5x FER improvement over the next best cooperative protocol.


One measure of academic impact of the project is the number of publications during the duration of the project; this project resulted about 30 publications involving authors from UCLA (that acknowledged support of this grant) in top tier conference and journals. It also supported (in part) the PhD work of two graduate students and a postodoctoral researcher, who have all gone on to careers in industrial research labs and academia. The work was disseminated  through several invited lectures in various industrial and academic settings by the PIs, and through organization of workshops.
